sources.full: Middle Finger of Vecna: Evil Archetypes

optionalfeature.name: Angel
entries: The image of an androgynous face with eyes serenely upturned to the heavens forms this mask, carved from flawless alabaster. When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can expend one spell slot to deal radiant damage to the target, in addition to the weapon's damage. The extra damage is {@damage 1d8} for a 1st-level spell slot, plus {@damage 1d8} for each spell level higher than 1st, to a maximum of {@damage 4d8}.
Beginning at 6th level, you can expend a Bardic Inspiration die as an action to heal a creature you touch by the amount rolled plus your bard level.

optionalfeature.name: Archmage
entries: This mask of deep purple fluorite is sculpted in the image of a heavily wrinkled old man. While wearing this mask, you have the spells {@spell burning hands}, {@spell expeditious retreat}, and {@spell magic missile} prepared in addition to the spells you have prepared. Beginning at 6th level, add can add {@spell gust of wind} and {@spell scorching ray} to your spells prepared.

In addition, at 6th level, when you deal damage with a spell, you can expend a Bardic Inspiration die as a bonus action to increase the damage dealt to each creature by the amount rolled + your Charisma modifier.

optionalfeature.name: Assassin
entries: Hardened black leather and metal clasps create the disturbing aspect of the assassin. While you are wearing this mask, you can deal an extra {@damage 1d6} damage to one creature you hit with an attack if you have advantage on the attack roll. The attack must use a finesse or a ranged weapon. You don't need advantage on the attack roll if another enemy of the target is within 5 feet of it, that enemy isn't incapacitated, and you don't have disadvantage on the attack roll.
This extra damage increases as you gain levels in this class. At 6th level, it increases to {@damage 2d6}, at 10th, it increases to {@damage 3d6}, and at 14th it increases to {@damage 4d6}.

Beginning at 6th level, when you make a melee attack against a creature who hasn't taken a turn in combat yet, you can expend a Bardic Inspiration die as a bonus action to increase damage your damage against that creature by the amount rolled.

optionalfeature.name: Beast
entries: Bright, flaking warpaint streaks this battered wooden image of a snarling, fang-toothed wild man. Whenever you make your first attack on your turn while wearing this mask, you can decide to attack recklessly. Doing so gives you advantage on melee weapon attack rolls using Strength during this turn, but attack rolls against you have advantage until your next turn.
In addition, beginning at 6th level, when you score a critical hit with a melee weapon attack, you can expend a Bardic Inspiration as a bonus action increase your damage by twice the amount rolled.

optionalfeature.name: Dragon
entries: This multihued mask of precious metals and scintillating gemstones forms the terrible visage of a snarling wyrm. While you wear this mask, you can use your action to exhale destructive energy. Each creature in a 15-foot cone must make Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 2d6} fire damage. You can use this ability a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier. When you finish a long rest, you regain all expended uses.
The damage of this ability increases as you gain levels in this class. At 6th level, it increases to {@damage 3d6}, at 10th it increases to {@damage 4d6}, and at 14th it increases to {@damage 5d6}.
Beginning at 6th level, you can expend a Bardic Inspiration die as a bonus action to gain resistance to an energy type of your choice for a number of rounds equal to the amount rolled.

optionalfeature.name: Faceless
entries: Only a pair of empty eyeholes break this otherwise featureless oval, porcelain mask. While you wear this mask, you have advantage on saving throws against spells.

At 6th level, you can use your action and expend a Bardic Inspiration die to teleport a distance up to your movement speed to a location you can see. If you teleport into a space that is already occupied by an object or creature, you take force damage equal to the number of feet traveled and are shunted to the nearest unoccupied location.

optionalfeature.name: Fiend
entries: This obsidian mask bears the visage of a darkly handsome demon or devil. Small, black horns adorn the fiend's forehead, and its black ears rise to points. You have resistance to fire and cold damage while you are wearing this mask.

At 6th level, you can invoke a demon's glare. Whenever another creature hits you with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to roll a Bardic Inspiration die and subtract it from the attack roll, potentially causing the attack to miss you.

optionalfeature.name: Gladiator
entries: This wyvern-hide mask is shaped like the face of a grim warrior. Scars cover its surface, and silver chainmail rings surround its outer edge. While you wear this mask, you have proficiency with medium armor and martial weapons.
Beginning at 6th level, when you make a melee weapon attack, you can expend a Bardic Inspiration die and add it to the attack roll.

optionalfeature.name: High Priest
entries: This mask of rose porphyry has a wide mouth open in song, but instead of eyes it has slits twisted into runes, which somehow do not restrict your vision. While wearing this mask, you have the spells {@spell bless}, {@spell detect evil and good}, and {@spell healing word} prepared in addition to the spells you have prepared. Beginning at 6th level, add {@spell aid} and {@spell zone of truth} to your spells prepared.

In addition, at 6th level, when you deal damage with a spell, you can expend a Bardic Inspiration die as a bonus action to increase the damage dealt to each creature by the amount rolled + your Charisma modifier.

optionalfeature.name: Monk
entries: This smoothly sanded wooden mask depicts the stern face of a bald man. While wearing this mask, you can use Dexterity instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls of your unarmed strikes, and your unarmed strikes deal {@damage 1d4} bludgeoning damage on a hit. Additionally, when you use the Attack action with an unarmed strike on your turn, you can make one unarmed strike as a bonus action.
Your unarmed strike damage die changes as you gain levels in this class. At 6th level, it increases to {@damage 1d6}, and at 14th level, it increases to {@damage 1d8}.

Beginning at 6th level, when you make an unarmed strike, you can use your bonus action and expend a Bardic Inspiration die to make two additional unarmed strikes. You can use your Bardic Inspiration die in place of your unarmed strike damage die for these attacks.

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, Neferat can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

trait.name: Cannibalism
entries: When Neferat reduces a creature to 0 hit points, she regains 22 ({@dice 4d10}) hit points.

trait.name: Gruumsh's Fury
entries: Neferat deals an extra 9 ({@damage 2d8}) damage when she hits with a weapon attack (included in the attacks).

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of her turn, Neferat can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls during that turn, but attack rolls against her have advantage until the start of her next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Neferat makes three attacks with her greataxe or spear.

action.name: Greataxe
entries: Melee Weapon Attack: {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 19 ({@damage 1d12 + 2d8 + 3} ) slashing damage

action.name: Spear
entries: Melee or Ranged Weapon Attack: {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. Hit: 15 ({@damage 1d6 + 2d8 + 2}) piercing damage, or 16 ({@damage 3d8 + 2}) piercing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.

Neferat is a terror to both orcs and man, and is the perfect type of villain to spring on your players when a marching army of goblinoids threatens the land. Importantly, she is a villain that threatens other conventional villains as well as the players, which might cause the party to ally themselves with orcs, bugbears, or factions of villains to stop her.
{@b Origin}
It is well-known that the strongest, most vicious orc ever to head an orc warband is a female named Neferat.

She was raised amongst the boys in a northern orc tribe, and taught to raid and hunt dragonborn settlements from a young age. Educated in violence, and deeply talented at it, Neferat killed her first orc chief at age nine, taking his tribe for her own. Disturbingly, even by orc standards, Neferat ate his body and crushed his bones in front of the whole tribe, earning her the infamous title 'Man-Eater.'

In the decades since, she has claimed dozens of tribes, amassing a terrifying force of warriors at her command. Her elite guard are a group of female orcs called the Harpies, who spare no enemy they encounter, and eat their victims, sometimes alive.

Neferat is a threat to orcs and man alike. Other orc warbands form temporarily, as a force of allied orcs under their respective warchiefs, but Neferat leaves no competitors for her throne, and has more warriors than any other tribe. If it were her wish, Neferat could unite all the orc tribes under one savage banner, but her goal appears to be the lands of men. With a few more tribes, her warband might be unstoppable, washing over nearby kingdoms with ease.
{@b Battling Neferat}

Neferat is never to be found without a cadre of bodyguards, typically three or four fiercely-loyal Harpies (NPC orc Berserkers.) However, Neferat is not one to shy away from a fight either. After identifying a threat and ordering her bodyguards into battle, Neferat will follow into combat one round later.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Persona is an 8th level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 16}, +7 to hit with spell attacks.) He has the following spells prepared:

trait.name: Masks
entries: Persona has four magic masks, each which confers a different property. He wears one at a time, and can switch his mask as a bonus action.

trait.name: Mask - Assassin : Sneak Attack (1/Turn)
entries: Persona deals an extra 11 ({@damage 3d6}) damage when he hits a target with a weapon attack and has advantage on the attack roll, or when the target is within 5 feet of one of Persona's allies that isn't {@condition incapacitated} and Persona doesn't have disadvantage on the attack roll.

trait.name: Mask - Beast: Reckless
entries: At the start of his turn, Persona can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls during that turn, but attack rolls against him have advantage until the start of his next turn.

trait.name: Mask - Faceless: Warded
entries: Persona has advantage on saving throws.

trait.name: Mask - Gladiator: Multiattack
entries: Persona makes three weapon attacks with his rapier.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Persona makes two attacks with his rapier or his light crossbow.

action.name: Rapier
entries: Melee Weapon Attack: {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 11 {@damage 1d8 + 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Light Crossbow
entries: Ranged Weapon Attack: {@hit 6} to hit, range 80/120 ft., one target. Hit: 7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage.

Persona is a theatric, mysterious villain, with more to him than it first seems. He makes a great bad guy for campaigns that rely on mystery and intrigue to drive the plot, since he can be anywhere, disguised as anyone. If you feel especially sadistic, you can even have Persona impersonate a party member, using a hat of disguise to look identical, and one of his masks to imitate that character's unique skills.
{@b Origin}

No one knows for certain who Persona was before he donned his first mask. Many speculate that he was a famous, now forgotten, stage performer, or a well-known, but ill-respected nobleman, but nothing more than incidental evidence truly points to these origins. Persona is an enigma; perhaps there is nothing behind his mask at all.

For years, a masked thief, conman, and impersonator has been a blight on the most powerful people of Pyremarch. No one has ever seen his face directly for Persona conceals his identity with a number of masks, painted to represent and mock archetypes of the stage. These masks bestow unique powers, related to the characters they represent, which makes Persona immensely as versatile in a fight as he is deadly. Beyond that, when he makes himself known, he wears the fineries of a nobleman, with no less than a dozen rings upon his fingers.

But most often, he is in disguise. Persona is perhaps the greatest performer that has ever lived; he can inhabit a role so completely as to fool the friends and families of the people he impersonates, which has allowed him to pull off truly incredible robberies and assassinations. He has amassed a small fortune, and made a deadly enemy of the Thieves' Guild, who he confounds at every turn.

It would appear that all of Persona's actions has been leading to something. The assassination of noblemen, the theft of powerful magic items, and the careful spread of misinformation has thrown the factions of the city into chaos. If he is not stopped, this single masked man might bring thousands to ruin.
{@b Battling Persona}

Persona is far more likely to flee combat than fight an entire party, but he is apt to put himself at risk in order to make a dramatic entrance or exit. Importantly, Persona often tries to charm his audience to sympathizing with his side, even though he rarely tells the truth.
You might encounter Persona flanked by a pair of official palace guards or a crowd of entranced townsfolk. Wherever he goes, he makes temporary allies to aide him in his goals.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Undolon is an 18th level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 18}, {@hit 10} to hit with spell attacks.) He has the following cleric spells prepared:
footerEntries: * Undolon casts these spells on himself before combat

trait.name: Divine Eminence
entries: As a bonus action, Undolon can expend a spell slot to cause his melee weapon attacks to magically deal an extra 10 ({@damage 3d6}) radiant damage to a target on a hit. This benefit lasts until the end of the turn. If he expends a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the extra damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each level above 1st.

trait.name: Sphere of Annihilation
entries: Undolon controls a sphere of annihilation, which he can direct to move up to 60 feet as a bonus action. A creature hit by the sphere takes {@damage 4d10} force damage. A creature killed by the sphere, or an object engulfed by it is completely obliterated.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Undolon makes two attacks: one with his entropic touch and one with his morningstar.

action.name: Entropic Touch
entries: Melee Spell Attack: {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 14 ({@damage 4d6}) force damage, plus 4 (an additional {@damage d6} for each die that rolled a 6.).

action.name: Morningstar
entries: Melee Weapon Attack: {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 8 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) force damage.

Undolon is a dangerous villain, with an army of spellcasters at his command. His schemes, though obviously mad to most observers, can threaten the very fabric of the multiverse. It's a good idea to include him as a higher-level villain, ideally in a campaign which spans the multiverse. He lends himself well to campaigns which are focused on collecting artifacts, or uncovering ancient lore, which needs a straightforward, but nonetheless threatening bad guy.
{@b Origin}

Entropy is simple: disorder, chaos, the end of all things. Chaos Priests teach that this is the natural state of the universe, and that Entropy is inevitable. If even the gods shall fall to the forces of Entropy, surely they are false gods, and only the true spirit of Entropy is deserving of worship.

Chaos Priests don't merely spread dangerous ideas, they spread danger. Subtly, and sometimes overtly with destructive magic, these clerics systematically destabilize regions and weaken governments, ushering in war, famine, and unrest. All this is but an extension of Entropy, and all things shall one day return to Entropy.

In spite of their ideology, the priests are anything but disorganized. They are led by a powerful hierophant named Undolon, who was once a cleric of Light. Undolon claims that, in a moment of divine insight, the Light illuminated the multiverse for him, allowing him to see it in totality for what it really is: a temporary façade, behind which there is only bottomless Entropy.

Beyond the echoes of chaos they spread in the world, Undolon's priests are also searching for and collecting the fragments of an immensely powerful spell: the Last Word. Legend tells that the word has the power to slay gods, and has done so in the past, but that no mortal can use it and survive. Truly, if Undolon completes the word, the universe itself may be thrown into anarchy.
{@b Battling Undolon}

Undolon is always flanked by six high priests of chaos (NPC priests), which help him conspire how best to use the chaos priests. Undolon is likely to send in his priests, three at a time, while he summons powerful help with a {@i gate} spell, in the form of a balor. Undolon knows this balor, who he calls D'thrius, personally and it will not attack him.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Goril is an 11th level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 17}, {@hit 9} to hit with spell attacks.) It has the following druid spells prepared:

trait.name: Blightfire
entries: When Goril begins its turn, all spaces adjacent to it become engulfed in flaming tar until the end of its next turn. When a creature other than Goril starts its turn in one of these spaces, it must succeed on a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw or take 18 ({@damage 4d8}) fire damage, or have as much on a successful save.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Goril has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Goril makes three attacks: two with its slam and one with its toxic touch.

action.name: Slam
entries: Melee Weapon Attack {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit 10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Toxic Touch
entries: Melee Spell Attack {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit 14 ({@damage 4d6}) poison damage, and the target must make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. An affected creature can repeat this save at the end of its turn, ending the effect on a success.

Goril acts more as a force of nature than a conventional villain. He's perhaps best employed as the cause of a great blight which ravages the land, or one specific forest, like the living embodiment of disease. Goril doesn't plan or lay elaborate traps, he just exists to spread the Waste.

When Goril is introduced, be sure to play up precisely how repulsive he is. Appearing more like a conglomeration of filth and tar than a humanoid creature, he leaves a trail of sludge in his waste. When he speaks, the voice comes from a stream of bubbles that surge to the surface around his body, distorting his voice into a sickening cacophony.
{@b Origin}

Once, a long time ago, Goril was an elf, and stood alongside the Circle of the Green, protecting the natural world from corruption. Because of his talent and ambition, Goril was called by the Parliament of Trees to serve as a Green Knight, the highest honor an elf could receive. He rose through the ranks and was eventually appointed the Verdant Captain, leader of the knights. As captain, he argued with the Parliament daily, urging them to let him strike out at the forces of corruption, rather than merely defending the forests from intruders. The Parliament denied him without fail.

Finally, Goril became impatient, and led a group into the Waste, where the Green Knights never venture. There, he found no terrible beasts or masses of sprawling corruption, but an endless, desolate plain, devoid of all life. As his knights began to perish from heat and thirst, something possessed Goril, and he turned on his brothers, slaying all who still stood.

When Goril returned to the Parliament, he carried inside of him a bit of the Waste, a malignant tumor of desolation, which he placed in the center of the forest. Life around it perished and become blighted, permanently destroying the Parliament of Trees and all the sacred groves. Gradually, Goril began to appear like the rot; festering, rotting, and steeped in corruption. Other elves fled the forest, and spat Goril's name, calling him the Lord of Maggots, and the King of Rot.
{@b Battling Goril}

Goril is followed by a pair of corrupted dire wolves (use Dire Wolf stats) that pounce on any living thing that comes into Goril's wake. Because Goril steadily transforms the landscape around him, the party is sure to fight him in difficult terrain, rife with hazards.

trait.name: Invisibility
entries: Roldin can cast the spell {@spell invisibility} at will.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Roldin has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Umbral Blade
entries: Roldin's longsword has reach, deals an additional {@damage 3d8} necrotic damage (included in the attack) and scores a critical hit on a roll of 18-20.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Roldin makes four attacks with his longsword.

action.name: Longsword
entries: Melee Weapon Attack: {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) slashing damage, or 10 ({@damage 1d10 + 5}) slashing damage if used with two hands, plus 13 ({@damage 3d8}) necrotic damage.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: Roldin adds 5 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, Roldin must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

reaction.name: Shift
entries: When a creature moves up to Roldin, he moves 10 feet away without provoking opportunity attacks.

Roldin is a dangerous solo combatant, and can be a useful tool in campaigns that require a background villain that can harass the players, and escape to fight another day. He is far more intimidating if placed against parties with a much lower level than his challenge, which is important to consider, because Roldin always fights alone.

There's a great deal of mystery in Roldin's backstory, which the players will have to learn to before defeating him once and for all. How did Roldin really get trapped in the Plane of Shadow, how did he survive, and how did he return? Is Roldin acting alone, or at the behest of a more powerful entity? The only people that know the answers to these questions were the knights of Roldin's past, now old men, and being picked off one at a time by the vengeful knight.

Roldin can also be adapted to campaigns which focus on other planes, rather than the Plane of Shadow. A portal to the Abyss, the Hells, or the Far Realm can provide a suitable alternate origin for Roldin as well.
{@b Origin}

Roldin was a young knight when the Long Night began. The sun simply never rose, and the land fell into chaos, as sinister creatures from under the earth arose to terrorize the surface. A mighty band of knights were summoned to restore order and daylight to the land. Roldin was counted among their number, as was his mentor, Kester the Brave.

Eventually, the band of knights found the source of the darkness, a decrepit mage's tower, swarming with living shadows. Somehow, the tower's resident had haphazardly opened a portal to the Plane of Shadow, which spiraled out of control, consumed the top floor of the tower, and caused an endless night.

The knights battled their way to the source of the disaster, slaying shadows as they went, but when they at last arrived, only Roldin and Kester still stood. As Kester tells it, both fought valiantly, but the void closed around Roldin, trapping him within. The other knights were revived, and given a hero's welcome upon returning home, but Roldin was never seen again. At least, that is, until a few weeks ago.

A knight in jet-black armor wielding Roldin's sword appeared out of thin air in the king's palace, slew Kester the Brave, and vanished just as quickly. Perhaps, the Black Knight only seeks revenge against the knights that once led him to the ill-fated tower, or perhaps he seeks to bring the Long Night again.
{@b Battling Roldin}

Roldin makes liberal use of his ability to become invisible at will, and prefers to strike unseen, and vanish quickly when his foe is slain. Only with a great deal of luck, and the ability to detect illusion magic, will the party ever catch him off-guard or interrupt one of his assassinations.

If he perceives the party to be a threat to his larger goals, or if the party successful impedes him, Roldin will strike them when they are at their most vulnerable: directly following a difficult fight with another foe, at the exact middle of a precarious rope bridge, or at night, when the campfire has just been extinguished.
Roldin is persistent, and does not sleep, eat, or drink. He will stalk his target for an extended time before striking, and is a devastating force when he appears.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Siddhartha has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: Siddhartha regains 10 hit points at the start of his turn if he has at least 1 hit point remaining. If Siddhartha takes radiant damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of his next turn.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: Siddhartha can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Siddhartha makes four unarmed strikes or makes two unarmed strikes and uses Thousand Deaths on one creature.

action.name: Animate Dead (1/Day)
entries: Siddhartha can cast the spell {@spell animate dead} as a 5th level spell.

action.name: Thousand Deaths
entries: Melee Attack: {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: If the target has less than half its hit points remaining, it must succeed a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, or be reduced to 0 hit points.

action.name: Unarmed Strike
entries: Melee Weapon Attack: {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 11 ({@damage 1d12}+5) bludgeoning damage + 5 ({@damage 1d8}) necrotic

Siddhartha is a villain straight out of a kung-fu horror movie, and is great for campaigns with strong horror or eastern influences, or as a refreshing change of pace for a campaign which doesn't typically venture into these themes.
{@b Origin}

Ki Vampires are known across the east, and are feared far more than any other type of undead, for while other undead lose their identities entirely, the Jiangshi persist as they were, with a deadly intelligence, and a lifetime of martial arts skill. Few know that the dreaded Jiangshi are, in fact, mortal, and fewer still know the story of Siddhartha, the immortal first of their kind.

Siddhartha traveled to the east from a far off land, over the mountains to trade spices and silks for gold. When his stocks were sold, and his coffers full, he intended to return home, but was ambushed on the road by ruthless bandits. Siddhartha was a generous man, and offered the men half his gold, a small fortune, if he could carry on safely to his homeland, but the bandits refused. Throwing him from his cart, the bandits took all he had, then broke both his legs and left him to die.

A day passed, and Siddhartha saw no one else upon the road, but watched a small, persistent light flicked high up in the mountains nearby. With heroic strength, the next morning he bound his legs with bamboo, and crawled up the mountain to find help. At the top, he found a monastery, full of kind monks, who fed him, nursed him back to health, and taught him the Way of the Open Palm, and of the ki that suffuses all of us.

Siddhartha stayed with the monks for a year and a day, learning all they had to teach him, but held inside him a seething hate for those who had assaulted him on the road. When he at last could walk, albeit with stiff legs, he left the monastery and found the bandit's hideout. In a rage, he killed everyone he found there, embracing the darkness within himself, and shunning balance with his ki.

In the decades to come, Siddhartha would refine the Way of the Jiangshi and take several pupils. His skin turned grey and withered, and before long, he was indistinguishable from a corpse. Indeed, Siddhartha has lived hundreds of years, and claimed hundreds of lives.

He seeks larger, more powerful spirits to drain and increase his own strength, and uses his army of Jiangshi to seek them out. Siddhartha covets the divine right of emperors and kings, especially, and seeks, whenever possible, to drain their ki to fuel his own.
{@b Battling Siddhartha}

Siddhartha is always to be found among no less than two Jiangshi warriors (use Vampire Spawn stats, but without the Vampire Weaknesses traits.) He will likely know of the party and the party's weaknesses before the fight, and will use this knowledge to his advantage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Ransom is a 15th level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 16}, {@hit 8} to hit with spell attacks). He has the following paladin spells prepared:

trait.name: Burn Effigy
entries: Ransom can use his bonus action to deal 11 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage to each creature adjacent to him.

trait.name: Unbeliever
entries: Ransom is immune to spells cast by clerics, druids, other paladins, and other divine sources.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Ransom makes two attacks with his longsword.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) slashing damage, or 10 ({@damage 1d10 + 5}) slashing damage if used with two hands, plus 13 ({@damage 3d8}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Blaspheme (1/Day) Day)
entries: Ransom speaks words of heresy, profound statements which shake the room. Each creature within 30 feet must make a Charisma saving throw ({@dc 16}) or be unable to restore hit points for one minute.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: Ransom adds 5 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit him. To do so, Ransom must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

Ransom is a very dangerous villain and makes a great match for higher-level parties, especially in campaigns with philosophical themes and grounded conflicts. Including him calls in to question the nature of divinity, and the personal ideals of law that the characters in your campaign hold.

The most terrifying aspect of Ransom is that he might be right on some level. As the GM, you have the final say on this, but casting some doubt on the gods themselves puts Ransom, the Defiants, and the entire campaign world in a very different light. With the right choice of Ransom's evidence, you can even reference the gaming medium as a whole, as the example below does.
{@b Origin}

Though his followers refer to him in hushed tones as Ransom the Truth Speaker or the First Defiant, most people simply call him That Damn Heretic. This was not always the case; Ransom was once a paladin of Law that stood vanguard against the forces of Chaos to protect the innocent.

But one day, while Ransom investigated a far corner of his king's domain for threats, he discovered something buried in a famer's field. The object had clearly fallen from the sky, and the moment Ransom laid his eyes on it, he forsook his gods, his oaths, and the very order of the universe. No one today knows what Ransom found, other than that it is irrefutable evidence that the gods are false, and so too may be the universe itself.

Ransom founded the Defiants, an organization of atheists, dedicated to destroying all faiths from their foundations. To his closest followers, Ransom showed the Evidence, which he keeps with him at all times, concealed at all times in a small cedar box. No one has ever glanced inside this box and kept their faith.

The defiants plot and scheme, where they must, and meet in the open where they can. It is their goal to convert all to their school of thought, and destroy all those who would oppose it. Though the temples of the Pantheon are strong and deeply-rooted, contingents of alchemists and arcanists have joined the cause as well -- science and reason are enough evidence for many.

It seems that the Defiants have been accelerating their goals in recent months. Ransom is pushing them to do something drastic; something related to his Evidence. If not stopped, the Defiants may fell the gods themselves, for without worship, divinity withers.
{@b Ransom's Evidence}
You can use a variety of artifacts in your campaign for Ransom's Evidence, but here's one suggestion that pokes fun at the gaming art form, and the existential crises that might emerge from it:

{@b The Icosahedron}. Ransom saw this artifact fall from the sky, and from beyond the sky. For an instant, he saw the edge of a Great Table, and immense legs of chairs, and understood that the beings above it all were not gods at all. The Icosahedron, a surprisingly dense 20-sided object, about a foot across, is engraved with strange symbols on each face. When it placed on the ground with one side facing up, those around it can feel the shifting of reality and the pull of fate. Some symbols are more powerful than others, for weal and for woe.
Lastly, when the Icosahedron is rolled, it imparts a sense of scale: The Icosahedron is from reality, and nothing else truly is.

Ransom has two goals for the icosahedron, which stem from his belief in justice and law: he wishes to return it to The Table from whence it came, and he wishes to use it to destroy the universe. The universe is false, a creation of the un-divine, and should be ended. Simultaneously, the Icosahedron belongs to the creators, and should be returned, that all things should be equal when it is over. Nothing else truly matters to him.

resist.note: from nonmagical weapons that aren't silvered

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Virgil is a 12th level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit 7} to hit with spell attacks). He has the following paladin spells prepared:

trait.name: Alert
entries: Virgil has advantage on initiative.

trait.name: Devil's Sight
entries: Magical dark ness doesn't impede Virgil's darkvision.

trait.name: Drain Soul (1/Day)
entries: Virgil can take one minute to feed on the soul of an {@condition unconscious} creature. The creature is killed, and can only be returned to life by means of a {@spell true resurrection} or {@spell wish} spell. Virgil's hit points are restored to maximum, and he regains all expended spell slots. Virgil must drain a soul at least every 7 days, or he withers and dies.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Virgil makes four attacks with his shortsword or two attacks with his shortsword and two with his infernal lash.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d6 + 1d8 + 5}) slashing damage. On a critical hit, the target must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} until the end of Virgil's next turn.

action.name: Infernal Lash
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit : 13 ({@damage 4d4 + 3}) necrotic damage .

reaction.name: Parry
entries: Virgil adds 5 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, Virgil must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

reaction.name: Wraith Form (1/Day).
entries: When Virgil takes damage, he becomes an incorporeal, flickering shadow. Until the beginning of his next turn, he is immune to damage from nonmagical weapons and is resistant to all other damage.

Virgil is a dark, mysterious character, and is great for campaigns which will eventually take place in the Hells, or one that needs a villain with a truly suicidal plot. Virgil, after all, has plenty of motivation to incite an epic disaster, as long as it is apocalyptic enough to completely destroy his immortal soul. He can also be a fun addition after the party comes across an artifact, since he might have reason to hunt them to secure it for himself.

Players can interact indirectly with Virgil through his writings on the Hells, as it plays a direct parallel to the real-world text Dante's Inferno. In his origin story, Virgil plays the part of Dante and himself, and walked through Hell for reasons now forgotten. He's a living character of legend, and emphasizing this can make for an imposing, memorable presence.
{@b Origin}
When you stare long into the abyss, the abyss stares back.

Virgil walked the depths of the Nine Hells centuries ago, but he, in his unnaturally long life, is still stained by its black influence. He penned his travels as he walked, and returned with his writings to the mortal world, and because of him, many scholars today know the torments that wait in the Hells. His writings detailed the different layers of the Hells, the types of devils roam its underbelly, and the names of the archdukes that reign on each layer. But Virgil's travels were not without cost.

Today, Virgil is himself a cross between a devil and a wraith himself. His body is still mortal, stuck in a halfway point between life and death, requiring him to drain the life force of the living to persist in the world.

Virgil is terrified of death, in spite of being a specter of death himself. He knows full well what evil awaits him in the afterlife, and so searches endlessly for an escape from his fate. Somewhere, he hoards scraps of ancient knowledge, and fragments of magical artifacts. His ultimate goal is to discover an artifact or ritual that can grant him an audience with the gods themselves, to beg for forgiveness and ask for entry into the higher planes. Failing that, Virgil looks for something powerful enough to destroy his soul, regardless of the collateral damage. Destroying the world would be acceptable to him, if he can avoid a return to the underworld in the process.

To many, his name is not that of a scholar, but that of a folk legend -- a moral tale warning children against the draw of evil things. Yet, Virgil is no legend; he prowls the world, feeding on the helpless, and searching for an escape from the Hells which await him.
{@b Battling Virgil}
Virgil never enters combat without an explicit goal. Normally, he reveals himself by casting either {@i fog cloud} (in the daytime) or {@i silence} (at night.)

Once he secures an artifact, or renders a victim unconscious to be drained of life, he will immediately flee to return the artifact to his hoard, or with his victim to drain it from safety. Unless something specifically prevents his escape, Virgil never battles to the death, and always ensures he has a good chance of victory or escape.
To secure his escape, Virgil may summon devils as a distraction. He never fights alongside the summoned devils, for he fears devils more than any living thing.

trait.name: Cunning Action
entries: On each of his turns, the Pale Man can use a bonus action to take the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action.

trait.name: Evasion
entries: If the Pale Man is subjected to an effect that allows him to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, he instead takes no damage if he succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if he fails.

trait.name: Pranks
entries: The Pale Man has gadgets which allow him to replicate the following cantrips as an 11th level spellcaster (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit 7} to hit with spell attacks): {@spell poison spray}, {@spell shocking grasp}, {@spell vicious mockery}

trait.name: Relentless (1/Day)
entries: If the Pale Man takes damage that would reduce him to 0 hit points, he is reduced to 1 hit point instead.

trait.name: Sneak Attack (1/Turn)
entries: The Pale Man deals an extra 13 ({@dice 4d6}) damage when he hits a target with a weapon attack and has advantage on the attack roll, or when the target is within 5 feet of an ally of the Pale Man that isn't {@condition incapacitated} and the Pale Man doesn't have disadvantage on the attack roll.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Pale Man makes two shortsword attacks and either throws a laughing gas bomb or a {@condition poisoned} dart.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing or fire damage. If a creature is reduced to 0 hit points by this weapon and dies, its corpse burns and crumbles to ash.

action.name: Laughing Gas Bomb
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 30/60 ft., one creature. {@h}10 ({@damage 4d4}) poison damage and the target, and all creatures within 5 feet of the target, must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or have disadvantage on attack rolls until the beginning of your next turn.

action.name: Poisoned Dart
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one creature. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d4 + 5}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving th row or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

reaction.name: Uncanny Dodge
entries: The Pale Man halves the damage against one weapon attack that hits him, then moves 5 feet without provoking opportunity attacks.

The Pale Man is a terrifying figure that most comic fans should recognize instinctively, (in spite of the fact that the character here is original, and any resemblance to any other figure, real or fictional, is purely coincidental.) He makes a great recurring villain, due to his propensity for survival in unlikely circumstances, and his amazing ability to create unique, convoluted schemes that that can fill up a session.
{@b Origin}
The Pale Man is an enigma. He is a jester and a murderer; a prankster and a psychopath.

Tales of the Pale Man go back for centuries, but the Pale Man himself would appear to be a young, otherwise healthy individual. Healthy, that is, except for the smiling grimace frozen across his face and his unnaturally white, almost bleached skin. At first blush, his appearance might appear jovial, but with time, it always unsettles and disturbs. His history is as unexplained as his appearance; many have heard of him, but none know his name, or from whence he originates.

For all intents and purposes, the Pale Man is a force of chaos. He plans and executes elaborate pranks, sometimes to fluster and amuse, and sometimes to maim and injure. Most often, it's a combination of both.

His tools of choice are gadgets and gas. The Pale Man has some experience with alchemy and tinkering, and loves to distort the tropes and gags of court jesters into tools of destruction. He's best known for laughing gas bombs, which provide a lethal punchline for his jokes, though he also employs lightning handshake buzzers and acidic flowers. If all else fails, he is extremely proficient with daggers, shortswords, rapiers, and other blades, and can end a confrontation swiftly if his jokes fall flat.

He travels frequently in secret, and wreaks havoc wherever he goes. Usually, he targets random individuals with his insidious schemes, but occasionally he will select one person he enjoys playing with, and menaces them without end.

Lastly, the Pale Man is extremely adept at surviving otherwise lethal circumstances. When an event would otherwise kill him, he is simply nowhere to be found when the smoke clears. It's possible that this is simply due to some luck, along with his unnatural quickness, but others have speculated that the Pale Man is more than he appears.
{@b Battling the Pale Man}

The Pale Man always keeps around a few colorful henchmen (NPC thugs) to assist him in his schemes, and if found at one of his temporary lairs, he will also have a pair of hyenas ready to be set loose.

The Pale Man is unpredictable, but also employs traps and pranks he has set up long in advance. If the odds turn against him, he will usually search for an inventive way of trying to destroy everyone, such as by bringing a building down, or by triggering a massive explosion. No matter how unlikely, as long as his death is not seen personally, his body is never recovered, and he somehow survives.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Patia is an 18th level spellcaster. Her spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 18}, {@hit 10} to hit with spell attacks.) She has the following sorcerer spells prepared:
footerEntries: * Patia casts these spells on her self before combat

trait.name: Overlord
entries: Patia can use her bonus action to command any number of undead under her control within 1 mile.

trait.name: Necrotic Healing
entries: When Patia would take necrotic damage, she instead regains hit points equal to the damage that would have been dealt.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The revenant regains 20 hit points at the start of its turn. If the revenant takes fire or radiant damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the revenant's next turn. The revenant's body is destroyed only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Rejuvenation
entries: When the revenant's body is destroyed, its soul lingers. After 24 hours, the soul inhabits and animates another corpse on the same plane of existence and regains all its hit points. While the soul is bodiless, a {@spell wish} spell can be used to force the soul to go to the afterlife and not return.

trait.name: Turn Immunity
entries: The revenant is immune to effects that turn undead.

trait.name: Vengeful Tracker
entries: The revenant knows the distance to and direction of any creature against which it seeks revenge, even if the creature and the revenant are on different planes of existence. If the creature being tracked by the revenant dies, the revenant knows.

action.name: Dagger
entries: Melee or Ranged Weapon Attack {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

Patia is a walking revenge story, with an entire undead horde at her back. She fits well into campaigns which feature massive, destructive undead hordes, as easily as she fits into those that favor inquisitive detective work, since one of the easiest ways to dispatch her is to unravel her past, and ensure that her vengeance is sated. Battling her and her horde directly is a challenge fit for a high-level party, while capturing Fax can be accomplished by a low level one.
{@b Origin}
Though her corpse bears little evidence, there is very little doubt that Lady Patia was once the fairest maiden in the land. Today, she is its greatest scourge.

Revenants rise when someone who meets a cruel and unjust death is given a rare second chance for vengeance. Lady Patia was a beautiful commoner turned wife of a nobleman, quite against her will. Her husband was Barnum Fax, a despotic nobleman who governed many estates in the East on behalf of the king and was infamous for his mistreatment for his property, including his servants, employees, and wives. However it was that Patia died, it was certainly by his hand, and was so savage that no one that witnessed it dare repeat its details. One year later, Patia's grave was found empty, dug up from the inside.

Patia is now a revenant and found that she was gifted with the Deathsign, a mark of undeath that can raise and contract the dead into service. She quickly raised an army of corpses and overran Fax's estates, forcing him to flee westward. The cowardly Fax is still on the run, pursued by an undead horde which sweeps the countryside, adding to their numbers wherever they travel. Over a year has passed, and yet Patia the Pale, as she has come to be known, clings to undeath, indicating that she is a revenant of the rarest variety, one gifted with a decade to seek vengeance against those who wronged her. Yet Fax remains hidden, and Patia's pale horde grows.
{@b Battling Patia}

Directly confronting Patia is no mean feat. She is perpetually followed by her undead horde, a mass of thousands of zombies, skeletons, and ghouls, with a handful of ghasts, wights, and ghosts mixed in. She only reveals herself directly when she thinks she has an opportunity to kill Barnum Fax. Even excluding that, she is a powerful sorcerer in her own right, with a talent for necromancy spells.

There is an alternate approach to dispatch Patia, without fighting through an army of undead. If the party can locate and kill Fax, Patia will return to the afterlife, and her undead will simple become inanimate. Of course, if finding him were easy, no doubt Patia would have managed it already–Fax seems to be protected by powerful magic.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The host's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 16}, {@hit 8} to hit with spell attacks) attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
footerEntries: * The host casts these spells on itself before combat

trait.name: Agonizing Blast
entries: The host adds its Charisma modifier to the damage it deals with eldritch blast on a hit.

trait.name: Host's Resilience
entries: The host uses its bonus action to gain 10 temporary hit points.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The host has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The host makes two mace attacks.

action.name: Mace
entries: Melee Weapon Attack {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 1d6 + 2d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, and the host regains hit points equal to half the damage dealt.

The parasite, X, is an alien enigma, and a great recurring villain for campaigns which have themes of extraterrestrial invasion, or any other type of body-snatcher. This villain lends itself well to political intrigue (for X prefers to take the rich and powerful as hosts) and murder-mystery adventurers, or any quest with the structure: "one of these people is secretly a monster."

X is amazingly difficult for the party to pin down, since it can escape through a string of bodies, and show up later wearing new skin. You can even, if you feel especially sadistic, secretly put X inside one of the party members for a nasty surprise.
{@b Origin}
The parasite is a creature from far beyond the stars that walks this earth wearing the skin of men.

No one is truly sure where it came from, or how it arrived here, but the parasite is certainly alien. Outside of its host, it appears to be a hideous bundle of tendrils and nerves, without any torso or core. Its true name is so complex as to be unpronounceable, perhaps approximated best as Xhateol'dagh, it is content to be called X by its hosts.

To most, X is no more than a myth, for it is almost never seen outside of its current host. It exchanges its hosts often, every few years in the best of circumstances, for it gradually drains and withers its host, leaving them no more than a husk.

When its host is spent, it makes a rare exposed trek to find a new one. It grapples a prospective host in its tendrils, then burrows into its body, taking up residence in the space between the host's body cavities. Once inside, it generally does one of three things: it can choose to negotiate with its host, offering magic and power, it can coerce its host by wreaking immense pain on its body, or it can simply kill the host and use its corpse as a puppet for a short while, until it begins to rot. One can track the parasite's travels by following a string of desiccated corpses and grisly murders.

To its hosts that accept it willingly, X can grant a pact, empowering its host with powerful magic as a warlock. In exchange, the host merely has to follow the parasite's telepathic commands, and allow the parasite to live within it. This pact is a deeply attractive offer, but comes with the eventual cost of the hosts own life, for the more magic the host uses, the greater toll the parasite takes on its system.

X is deeply secretive with its goals on this planet. Perhaps, it is an advance scout, the first invader before an armada arrives. Or maybe it is simply stranded here, and is searching for a way to return to its home. Perhaps, even, X is the last of its kind, and simply wants to survive, or find a way to reproduce.
{@b Battling X}

X has a different host each time he is encountered, (the following statistics represent a generic human host.) It will normally fight without abandon, without fear for his host's life, as long as there is another potential host nearby. If defeated, it will attempt to flee into the nearest living body and escape.

If it is aware that the party poses a threat to its ultimate goals, X may simply inhabit a less-inconspicuous, but very powerful host, like a fully-grown minotaur, and attempt to end the problem once and for all. Most other times, however, X prefers a stealthier approach, and will try to pick the party off one person at a time.
{@b Host Template}

The parasite can take a huge number of creatures as hosts. A beast, humanoid, giant, or monstrosity can become a Host. When a creature becomes a host, it retains all its statistics, except as noted below.
Damage Resistances. The host gains resistance to cold, fire, lightning, and poison damage.
Senses. The host gains blindsight with a range of 120 feet and can telepathically communicate with its host.
Host's Resilience. The host can use its bonus action to gain 10 temporary hit points.
Magic Resistance. The host has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.
Innate Spellcasting. The host's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save DC 17, +8 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
Cantrips (at will): {@i eldritch blast, mage hand, minor illusion}
At will: {@i detect magic, false life, levitate, mage armor*}
3/day each: {@i darkness, hellish rebuke, hold person, invisibility, ray of enfeeblement, shatter}
1/day each: {@i bestow curse, dimension door, eyebite, finger of death, polymorph}
*The host casts these spells on itself before combat
Leeching Strike. When the host deals damage with a melee weapon attack, it regains hit points equal to half the damage dealt.
{@b Losing the Template}

If a host is reduced to 0 hit points, its parasite will exist the host's body in search of a new host, removing this template from that creature. The parasite might choose to leave if another potential host shows much more potential, or if it needs to disguise itself as another creature for a while.

While without a host, the parasite has AC 10, 25 hit points, and a movement speed of 5 feet. It can grapple a potential host as an action (escape DC 15) and enter a creature it has grappled as an action, bestowing this template upon it. It can enter an unconscious creature without grappling it.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Faust is an 18th level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 17}, {@hit 9} to hit with spell attacks.) He has the following wizard spells prepared:
footerEntries: * Faust casts these spells on himself before combat

trait.name: Infernal Allies
entries: Faust is under the careful watch of fiends, who can send a powerful ally to support him. One round after he first takes damage, a {@creature horned devil}, and four {@creature lemure|MM|lemures} automatically teleport to unoccupied spaces within 15 feet of Faust, and immediately attack creatures that are hostile to him. Faust can suppress the summoning of his allies, if he so chooses. Additionally, Faust can use his action to summon an {@creature imp}, which follows his commands. He can have 3 imps at a time summoned in this way.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Faust has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

Senator Faust is the envoy for a great devil, and is the perfect mastermind for a political campaign. His goals are nefarious, and his means are insidious, and, best of all, he can summon devils to challenge the party.

It's best to introduce Faust in the background, as the mastermind of the plot, and allow the party to follow their deduction to learn of him, and uncover his backstory. He's a tragic figure (as is the classic character of literature he borrows his name from) and the party might choose to find a way to deal with the Advocate, to ensure that Faust is let free from his bargain.
{@b Origin}
For all intents and purposes, Faust is a mad genius. He's a skilled politician, diplomat, and arcanist, all of which serve him well when bargaining with devils.

Faust's story is a tragic one, that of a brilliant man trying to best fate. When he was still an apprentice wizard, Faust married young, and was deliriously happy (as young people are) but by the time he was mere months from becoming a Master of the Conjuration school, something was wrong. His wife developed a cough, and began to lose the feeling in her fingers. She eventually bore him a daughter, but perished in childbirth, and the child was born very ill. Clerics, healers, and other wizards visited in turn, but none could do anything to alleviate the sickness.

Faust, in his desperation, sought a solution from more powerful forces. He knew that if the gods would not help, the devils below would. But rather than summon one to the Material Plane to negotiate with, Faust chose a more daring option: with a dark ritual, he traveled alone to the Nine Hells and sought out a devil named the Advocate. Because he met the Advocate on his terms, he thought he could negotiate a better deal from the fiend, and perhaps could save his child from death. The Advocate suspended time in his domain, and negotiated with Faust for years. The two eventually came to an agreement that Faust believed to be free of any loopholes or disadvantages. He was wrong.

Faust returned to the mortal realm not as a wizard, but as a senator, one of the most powerful in the land. This was just one of the many perks that Faust had bargained to achieve. Another was an imp familiar to assist him in his schemes.

To complete his bargain with the Advocate, Faust must complete three monstrous tasks from his seat as senator. First, Faust must have the king assassinated by a profane dagger, and ensure that his brother, a wicked servant of the Advocate, would ascend to the throne. Second, he must cause a great disaster within the nation, one that shall cost thousands of innocent lives in the Advocate's name. Lastly, he must open a gate to the Advocate's domain in the Nine Hells, allowing innumerable devils to stream forth into the mortal realm. Only then will Faust be able to remedy his child.
{@b Battling Patia}

Faust is a very difficult enemy to attack in part because he's a powerful government official. He takes great care to disguise his malicious activity, so that any actions against him seem unjustified, illegal, and treasonous. In public, he is never far from a small detachment of well-trained guards, (NPC veterans) and even at home, a pair of personal guards are never out of earshot.

But these protectors are nothing compared to the infernal allies that Faust can call upon. His work is deemed very important by the Advocate, and so a host of devils are automatically summoned to his location whenever Faust would prove to be in mortal danger. Of course, he makes good to never allow his infernal friends to expose him, so he rarely summons them in public places, unless the situation is truly dire or he is confident that he can deal with all the witnesses.

subclassFeature.name: School of Diabolism
entries: You have long considered that power is most often profane. Vile fiends, which reside in eternal pits of flame outside the mortal realm, wield power that puts the works of mortal men to shame. Yet, they are unequivocally evil and going so far as to strike a bargain with one is worthy of damnation. Through intense study of obscure summoning and binding rituals, you've reached out to the Lower Planes and have contacted a fiend yourself, not to parlay with, but to command.

entries.name: Vile Knowledge
entries: By 2nd level, you are well versed in all manner of occult rituals and fiendish summons, and have advantage on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) checks involving them.

entries.name: Imp Familiar
entries: At 2nd level, you add the {@spell find familiar} spell to your spellbook, if it was not there already. When you summon your familiar, you can instead summon an {@creature imp} which obeys your commands as a familiar does. As a bonus action on your turn, you can command your imp familiar to perform an action or make an attack.

subclassFeature.name: Anchor of Hell
entries: At 6th level, as an action you can select 1 creature you can see within 30 feet to make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, for the next minute every foot the creature moves costs 1 extra foot. After using this ability, you must complete a short or long rest before using it again.

subclassFeature.name: Devil's Advocate
entries: By 10th level, you are exceptionally shrewd at infernal negotiations, and have advantage on Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) checks made against fiends. Additionally, the time required for you to cast the {@spell find familiar} spell as a ritual to summon an imp is reduced to 1 action.

subclassFeature.name: Form Pact
entries: Beginning at 14th level, by expending a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, a spell slot of 5th level or higher, and a pint of fresh blood, you can perform a ritual requiring 1 hour of concentration to summon a fiend from the lower planes.

By sacrificing a living, intelligent creature to the fiend, or by sacrificing a great quantity of your own blood to the fiend (reducing your hit points by half your maximum, and reducing your Constitution score by 2 until you complete a long rest) you can gain one of the following benefits for the next 24 hours:

items: You can enlist the services of a {@filter fiend of challenge 5 or lower|bestiary|challenge rating=[&0;&5]|type=fiend} for a day. Roll initiative for the fiend, which has its own turns. The fiend disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or at the end of 24 hours. The fiend is friendly to you and your companions for the duration but otherwise acts according to its alignment. It obeys any verbal commands that you issue to it (no action required by you), but can interpret the command insidiously if proper wording isn't used. If you don't issue any commands to the fiend, it defends itself from hostile creatures but takes no other actions.
You can gain resistance to nonmagical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage for the duration.
When you roll damage for a spell, you can reroll a number of the damage dice up to your Intelligence modifier. You must use the new rolls.
You can cast any {@filter spell of 7th level or lower|spells|level={&0;&7} once in the next 24 hours without expending a spell slot or spell components.

entries: After making a pact, your pact must end and you must take a long rest before making another.

subclassFeature.name: College of Masks
entries: Bards in the College of Masks, known as Masters of Masks by other bards, are virtuoso performers who practice becoming the figure they portray, rather than merely imitating them. Bards in this college believe that all life is performed, rather than lived, and that to become an actor in this Great Play requires that one merely puts on the metaphorical mask of another. Because each person wears a mask every day, a Master of Masks carries with him a number of masks, each a potent magical artifact of a specific archetypical character or creature to allow them to better enter those roles.

entries.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: When you join the College of Masks at 3rd level, you gain proficiency in {@skill Deception} and {@skill Performance}. If you are already proficient in one of these skills you can choose instead another skill proficiency from among those bards can choose at 1st level.

entries.name: Persona Masks
entries: At 3rd level, you learn to craft potent magical {@filter masks|optionalfeatures|feature type=mask}, each of which allows you to take on a different persona and gain some aspect of that archetypical character. You begin with two persona masks of your choice. You can only use masks created by yourself and no one else (even another Master of Masks) can benefit from a persona mask you create. You can switch masks as a bonus action.
You can create two additional masks at 6th level, and one more at 14th level.

subclassFeature.name: Hidden Mask
entries: By 6th level you wear a mask, even when others cannot see it. You can use your bonus action to cause a mask you wear become invisible, or return an invisible mask to visibility.

subclassFeature.name: Master of Many Masks
entries: At 14th level, you are a master of assuming the archetypes contained within the masks. You can wear two masks simultaneously, gaining the benefits of each.

subclassFeature.name: The Parasite
entries: Most warlocks make pacts with dead gods and foreign, intangible spirits, and therefore always have cause to doubt their patron's veracity. By contrast, you have assurance of your patron's power, for it dwells within you. And not in a metaphorical sense; your patron literally lives inside of you. Others would call your patron a parasite, and you merely a host, but you know the truth.

Your patron is a rare, powerful creature, perhaps the last of its kind. It is foreign to this world or incredibly ancient, and to remain healthy, it must take up residence inside a host. In compensation, it offers immense power and eldritch secrets to the creature that carries it. You took this creature's bargain willingly, accepted its power, and invited its voice into your head.

entries.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The Parasite lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

subclassFeature.name: Leeching Strike
entries: At 1st level, your patron has taught you to feed off of others, just as it feeds off of you. Once per turn, when you deal damage with a melee weapon attack, you gain temporary hit points equal to half the damage dealt, rounded down, up to a maximum of your warlock level.

subclassFeature.name: Agitate Magic
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can use your bonus action to call upon your parasite to disrupt foreign magic around you. For up to 1 minute, you have resistance to damage you take from spells and advantage on saving throws against them. During this time, you take irreducible and unavoidable {@damage 1d8} damage at the beginning of your turn, as your patron feeds on you to fuel the effect. You can end this effect early on your turn, but you take an immediate 10 damage.

subclassFeature.name: Host's Resilience
entries: At 10th level, your patron shares some of its vitality with you. When you roll initiative, you gain 10 temporary hit points which remain for up to 1 minute.

subclassFeature.name: Transfer Host
entries: By 14th level, you can use your action to transfer your parasite patron to another host within your reach. For 1 minute, at the beginning of each of its turns, the target must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the target is {@condition paralyzed} until the end of its turn, and takes 25 points of irreducible damage. Constructs, elementals, and undead automatically succeed this saving throw.

While your parasite is outside your body, you are left with only remnants of your magical abilities, and cannot cast spells of 1st level or higher, nor can you use any powers or abilities offered by this patron.

At the end of this duration, or when the new host is reduced to 0 hit points, your parasite is ejected from the hosts body, and lands in a space adjacent to the creature. While without a host, the parasite has AC 10 and 10 hit points. If it is reduced to 0 hit points, the parasite is gravely injured, and you will be unable to cast spells of 1st level or higher until you complete a long rest with it inside your body. You can reabsorb your parasite as a bonus action.

If you transfer your parasite to a host whose challenge rating is greater than your level, there is a {@chance 50} chance, at the GM's discretion, it will choose to remain with its new host. If this is the case, it imposes no negatives on the target, and will only return if the host is reduced to 0 hit points.
After using this ability, you must complete a long rest before using it again.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Jiangshi
entries: All living things are inhabited by two types of ki energy, positive ki and negative ki, often called yin and yang. When a spirit is in harmony, the yin and yang are in balance, and when a spirit is in discord, one energy overpowers the other, and throws the creature into chaos, mentally and physically.

The Jiangshi are an order of monks that have shunned harmony, and embraced negative ki within their own spirits. These monks have discovered that a spirit suffused with negative ki can achieve a type of balance of its own, as it becomes sustained by the necromantic energies of negative ki itself.

Commoners often call the Jiangshi ‘ki vampires,' because of their unique ability to draw ki energy from a living creature, and because their negative ki influences their bodies in horrifying ways, making them appear like shades of death.

entries.name: Semblance of Death
entries: Starting whenever you chose this tradition at 3rd level, your skin becomes a sickly grey and your joints stiffen in a perpetual rigor mortis, causing you to adopt a unique style of fighting. To move, you hop and bend abruptly, and other creatures have disadvantage on opportunity attacks against you.

entries.name: Steal Ki
entries: At 3rd level, whenever you reduce a creature to 0 hit points, you regain spent ki points equal to half your proficiency bonus, rounded down.

subclassFeature.name: Perfect Undeath
entries: At 6th level, as an action, you can gain temporary hit points equal to twice your monk level, which last for one minute. Once you use this feature, you must complete a short or long rest before using it again.

subclassFeature.name: The Dead Walk
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can cast the spell {@spell animate dead} without using a spell slot or spell components. After using this ability, you must complete a long rest before using it again.

subclassFeature.name: A Thousand Deaths
entries: At 17th level, you can fatally drain a creature of ki. You can use your action and spend 4 ki points to make an unarmed strike against a creature that has less than half its hit points remaining. This creature must succeed a Constitution saving throw or be reduced to 0 hit points.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Cannibal
entries: A barbarian that follows the Path of the Cannibal is truly a monster to behold. Only man-eaters, as they are called, hunt men for sport, and do it with such grisly intent. They believe that when they consume their foes' flesh, they destroy that creature's eternal soul and absorb part of its essence into their own. Of course, such beliefs are barbaric, by even the standards of most primitive cultures, but the ferocity of a man-eater is, regardless, known the world-over.

entries.name: Consume Flesh
entries: Starting at 3rd level, whenever you reduce a creature to 0 hit points while raging, you regain hit points equal to twice your barbarian level. In addition, until the beginning of your next turn, you have advantage on ability checks and saving throws.

subclassFeature.name: Manhunter
entries: At 6th level, you can add twice your proficiency bonus to any ability check you make when hunting or tracking humanoid creatures. You can track humanoids while traveling at a fast pace, and you can move stealthily while traveling at a normal pace.

subclassFeature.name: Grim Visage
entries: By 10th level, most people consider you more of a monster than a man. While you're raging, you can attempt to intimidate one creature within 5 feet of you as a bonus action. It must succeed a Wisdom saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) modifier), or be {@condition frightened} of you until the end of your next turn.
Once a creature makes a saving throw against this ability, you can't use it again on that creature for 24 hours.

subclassFeature.name: Consume Soul
entries: At 14th level, whenever you reduce a creature to 0 hit points while raging, you can use your bonus action to devour its essence. Doing so cures you of any disease or curse afflicting you, removes all levels of exhaustion you may have, and also ends any of the following conditions affecting you: {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, and {@condition poisoned}.
Additionally, for the next minute, you have advantage on saving throws.
The creature you target with this ability can be restored to life only by means of a {@spell true resurrection} or a {@spell wish} spell.

subclassFeature.name: Entropy Domain
entries: Entropy, the end of all things, the return to chaos. Those who follow deities of this domain are rarely anything other than evil, and want all things to return to the chaos in which the universe originated.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: When you choose this domain at 1st level, you gain proficiency in {@filter heavy armor|items|source=null|type=heavy armor} and {@filter martial weapons|items|source=null|type=Martial Weapon}.

subclassFeature.name: Entropic Touch
entries: At 2nd level, your touch can increase entropy and wither the life from living things. Make a melee spell attack against a creature within your reach. On a hit, that creature takes {@damage 1d6} force damage. If one of these dice rolls a 6, roll an additional d6, rolling again if this die rolls a 6, and so on, to a maximum of {@damage 4d6} damage for the entire attack. This attack's damage increases by {@damage 1d6} and its maximum damage increases by {@damage 2d6} when you reach 5th level ({@damage 2d6} / {@damage 6d6}), 11th level ({@damage 3d6} / {@damage 8d6}), and 17th level ({@damage 4d6} / {@damage 10d6}).

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Distortion Field
entries: At 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to increase or accelerate or decelerate entropy in a region of space. As an action, choose a 10-foot radius sphere that you can see within 30 feet. For {@dice 1d6} rounds, while you concentrate on this effect, whenever a creature enters the affected area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, the creature takes {@damage 2d6} necrotic damage. Alternatively, you can instead heal each creature in this region {@dice 2d6} hit points once at the time of casting.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Return to Entropy
entries: At 6th level, you learn to use your Channel Divinity to repair or destroy objects. As an action, you may repair or damage one unattended non-magical object which has an area in cubic feet less than five times your Cleric level. Objects heal or take {@dice 8d8} force damage from this effect.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Strike
entries: By 8th level, you gain the ability to infuse your strikes with divine energy. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can cause the attack to deal an additional {@damage 1d8} force damage. At 14th level this increases to {@damage 2d8}.

subclassFeature.name: Sphere of Annihilation
entries: By 17th level, you can create a pocket of pure entropy so energetic that it forms a hole in the multiverse, a sphere of annihilation. This sphere is less stable than a normal sphere of annihilation and as such behaves differently. Your sphere is a 2-foot diameter black sphere that appears in your square and dissipates after one minute. Non-magical items that are wholly engulfed by the sphere are obliterated. Anything other than a magic item that touches the sphere but isn't wholly engulfed by it takes {@damage 4d10} force damage.

You can move the sphere 15 feet in any direction as a bonus action. If the sphere enters a space a creature occupies, the creature must make a Dexterity saving throw or be touched by it, taking {@damage 4d10} force damage. If a creature is killed by this damage, its body is disintegrated, its soul is consumed, and can only be restored to life with a {@spell wish} spell. After you create a sphere of annihilation, you cannot create another one until you complete a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of Heresy
entries: You have seen the truth. The great prophets of history are false, and their clerics have been deceived; the gods are not what we thought they were. Your great revelation was a crystallizing moment, fulfilled by your oath. You will spread the truth with your voice to whoever has ears to listen, and where that does not dispel the lies, your sword might dispense its own truth.

entries.name: Tenets of Heresy
entries: Heretics are forged in fire and live by different creeds, but they universally share the following beliefs.

entries.name: The Gods are a Lie
entries: Your revelation has shown you this that the gods as people know them do not exist, and you may never again accept a religion founded upon them.

entries.name: Their Prophets are False
entries: Prophets of false gods, including their clerics, paladins, and priests, shall be shown the truth. If they continue to spread their lies, they shall be put to death and their temples destroyed.

entries.name: Steal from the Gods
entries: You can siphon off the power of the gods, using it to cast your own 'divine' magic, weakening the gods in the process.

entries.name: Reveal the Truth
entries: Your message will never be accepted easily, for people hold strongly to their beliefs. You must make them see the truth.

entries.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed.

entries.name: Channel Divinity
entries: When you take this oath at 3rd level, you gain the following two Channel Divinity options.

entries.name: Blaspheme
entries: You speak words of heresy, profound statements which shake the room. Each unfriendly creature within 30 feet must make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is unable to magically regain hit points for 24 hours.

entries.name: Burn Effigy
entries: You can immolate your foes as an effigy of the gods. Choose a humanoid that you can see within 30 feet. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} while you maintain concentration on this effect, to a duration of 1 minute, and take {@damage 2d6} fire damage. At the end of each of its turns, the target can make another Wisdom saving throw, ending the effect on a success. On a failure, the creature takes an additional {@damage 1d6} fire damage.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of Disbelief
entries: At 7th level, your iconoclasm disempowers the servants of the gods. You and all friendly creatures within 10 feet of you have advantage on saving throws against divine spells, those cast by clerics, paladins, druids, rangers, and other sources the GM deems appropriate.
At 18th level, the range of this aura increases to 30 feet.
